title-group.article-title: Reconstruction of the late-Holocene changes in the Sub-Arctic Front position at the Reykjanes Ridge, north Atlantic

article-meta.aff: 1Leibniz Institute for Baltic Sea Research, Germany
2Uni Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research, Norway
4Université de Bordeaux, CNRS, UMR 5805 EPOC, France
5Geological Survey of Denmark and Greenland, Denmark

author-notes.corresp: Matthias Moros, Leibniz Institute for Baltic Sea Research, Seestrasse 15, 18119 Rostock, Germany. Email: matthias.moros@io-warnemuende.de, matthias.moros@bjerknes.uib.no

abstract.p: Changes in the dynamics of the North Atlantic subpolar gyre are involved in the modulation of the northward salinity and heat transport in the northern North Atlantic via the North Atlantic Current (NAC). Variations in the strength of the East Greenland Current (EGC) can influence the gyre dynamics by impacting deep convection in the Labrador Sea. Oxygen isotope data of three planktonic foraminiferal species (surface water Neogloboquadrina pachyderma dextral coiling and Globigerina bulloides; thermocline recorder Globorotalia inflata) from a site located close to the present Sub-Arctic Front at the Reykjanes Ridge suggest significant strengthening or shifting of the Sub-Arctic Front throughout the late Holocene. The oxygen isotope based inferences are supported by Mg/Ca-derived temperature reconstructions from Neogloboquadrina pachyderma dextral coiling, alkenone-derived sea surface temperature and other paleoclimatic proxy data. The late-Holocene strengthening/shift of the Sub-Arctic Front appears caused by an increasingly more defined and fresher EGC. The proposed subpolar gyre changes may modulate the northward heat transport, and explain the geographically different long-term climatic trends in the North Atlantic during the late Holocene, i.e. a cooling of the EGC-influenced regions and a warming of the NAC-influenced areas from c. 4 to 5 ka. This mechanism cannot, however, explain the simultaneous occurrence of millennial-scale events at c. 5.6, 3.9, 2.7, 1.3 ka and the ‘Little Ice Age’ in both areas. Noteworthy is the steadily increasing amplitude of these cold events at the Reykjanes Ridge, likely induced by drift ice and/or EGC-influence culminating in the ‘Little Ice Age’. A widespread pronounced warming at 2.0 ka seems to represent the ‘Roman Warm Period’ and reflects the warmest period of the late Holocene.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Studies over the last few years have demonstrated that Holocene climate development is not uniform in the North Atlantic region (e.g. Andersen et al., 2004; de Vernal and Hillaire Marcel, 2006; Giraudeau et al., 2010; Kaufman et al., 2004; Moros et al., 2004, 2006a; Solignac et al., 2004). This provincialism seems to be closely linked to the surface water mass distribution in the northern North Atlantic (e.g. Bond et al., 2001; Hald et al., 2007). Two main currents determine the surface water conditions (Figure 1), the warm North Atlantic Current (NAC) and the cold East Greenland Current (EGC). The NAC, which draws waters from the subpolar (SPG) and subtropical (STG) gyres (Figure 1), forms the surface limb of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation. The SPG circulates cyclonically (counterclockwise) between 50° and 65°N and contains strong boundary currents (e.g. Cuny et al., 2002). It is a region of intense interaction between ocean and atmosphere: wintertime cold winds cause intense deep convection. The newly formed subpolar waters merge with the overflows from the Nordic Sea to form the North Atlantic Deep Water. The warm saline STG circulates anticylonically (clockwise). The strength of the modern NAC and thus the inflow of warm and saline waters into the Nordic Seas is to a large extent controlled by the dynamics of the SPG circulation on interannual to interdecadal timescales (Häkkinen and Rhines, 2004; Hansen and Østerhus, 2000; Hátún et al., 2005). Strong SPG circulation results in a more east–west oriented SPG, contributing more low salinity water to the NAC. In contrast, a weak SPG circulation results in a more north–south oriented SPG, which contributes less low salinity water to the NAC. This concept, observed in the instrumental data was used by Thornalley et al. (2009) to explain paleoceanographic and climatic changes during the Holocene southeast of Iceland.

caption.p: Core site DS97-02P, surface water circulation (EGC: cold East Greenland Current; EIC: cold East Iceland Current; NAC: warm North Atlantic Current; IC: Irminger Current) and frontal systems (SAF: Sub-Arctic Front; AF: Arctic Front) in the North Atlantic. Numbers 1 to 7 mark sites of published records pertinent to this study. The position of the subpolar gyre (SPG) and the subtropical gyre (STG) are indicated.

sec.p: The modern SPG dynamics is also closely linked to buoyancy forcing associated with deep convection in the Labrador Sea (Häkkinen and Rhines, 2004). Significant freshwater input via the EGC may prevent deep convection over longer timescales (Hillaire-Marcel et al., 2001). Several studies indicate a stronger and likely fresher EGC east of Greenland and North of Iceland during the late Holocene (e.g. Andersen et al., 2004; Andrews et al., 1997; Eiriksson et al., 2000; Giraudeau et al., 2010; Jennings et al., 2002, 2011; Kristjánsdóttir et al., 2007; Moros et al., 2006a). An increasingly colder West Greenland Current, supplied by a colder and fresher EGC is reported for the late Holocene from West Greenland (Moros et al., 2006b; Perner et al., 2011). The strength of the EGC determines the position of the Sub-Arctic Front south of Iceland. A stronger EGC sharpens the Front (strengthens the gradient with the NAC) and moves the Sub-Arctic Front to the southeast. Although there is a general tendency of a topographic control of the Sub-Arctic Front by the Reykjanes Ridge topography (Sy et al., 1992), temporal variability of the Front’s position during the past decades has been well documented (Belkin and Levitus, 1996; Bersch et al., 2007). The latter authors noted frontal migration to be linked to atmospheric forcing and changes in EGC behavior. High-resolution paleoclimate records from sites close to the Sub-Arctic Front south of Iceland would thus allow for detailed reconstructions (i) of the EGC properties, and (ii) of the mechanism resulting in changes in SPG dynamics during the late Holocene.

Our study area at the Reykjanes Ridge is close to the present Sub-Arctic Front position (Figure 1) and well suited to monitor late-Holocene changes in the strength of the EGC. Based on new oxygen isotope data of the three planktonic foraminiferal species Neogloboquadrina pachyderma dextral coiling (d.), Globigerina bulloides and deep-dweller Globorotalia inflata, Mg/Ca-derived sea-surface temperature data on N. pachyderma d. compared with alkenone biomarker paleothermometry, coccolith abundance and species counts and diatom sensus data, we infer late-Holocene trends and variability of EGC influence on the Sub-Arctic Front in the study area.

sec.title: Oceanographic settings
sec.p: The coring site at the Reykjanes Ridge (Figure 1) underlies the northwestward moving Irminger Current which is a branch of the poleward moving relatively warm, saline surface waters of the NAC that enters the Nordic Seas east of Iceland. Present summer sea-surface temperatures (SST) range from 9 to 12°C (e.g. Levitus and Boyer, 1994; World Ocean Atlas, 2009 (available at: http://www.nodc.noaa.gov/OC5/WOA09/pr_woa09.html); Wright and Worthington, 1970). These temperatures can, however, fluctuate strongly because of the variable input of polar water from the EGC (e.g. Levitus and Boyer, 1994). The coring site is located in the central North Atlantic and near the Sub-Arctic Front (Belkin and Levitus, 1996), which is not as sharply developed as its equivalent in the Nordic Seas, the Arctic Front. The northeast-to-southwest trending Arctic and Sub-Arctic Fronts separate the warm from the cold, seasonally ice-carrying waters (Figure 1). They are thus coincident with the maximum extent of winter drift ice. Instrumental, historical and proxy data have documented rapid and large changes in the position of the Arctic and Sub-Arctic Frontal systems over a wide range of timescales.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: Core DS97-2P was collected during the Dutch Denmark Strait expedition in 1997 with the R/V Professor Logachev (Troelstra et al., 1997). The core (10.4 m length) was obtained from Reykjanes Ridge (58°56.327′N, 30°24.590′W) from a water depth of 1685 m (Figure 1) in the vicinity of core LO09-14 (Berner et al., 2008; Moros et al., 2004).

sec.title: Chronology
sec.p: The chronology of the mid- to late-Holocene part (upper c. 160 cm core depth covering the time span 5.9 to 0.7 ka) of core DS97-2P is based on 13 AMS 14C dates (Figure 2, Table 1). The upper date was not used. Seven dates were already published in Prins et al. (2001) and Rasmussen et al. (2002). AMS 14C dates (see Table 1) were calibrated using Marine09 in Calib6.01 (Stuiver and Reimer, 1993) and applying a reservoir age of 400 yr. All ages referred to in this paper are calibrated kiloyears BP 1950 (ka).

caption.p: The age/depth model developed for core DS97-02P. For AMS 14C dates refer to Table 1.

DS97-02P Piston core. AMS 14C dates were performed at Poznan Radiocarbon laboratory (Poz-numbers) and at Utrecht AMS facility (UtC-numbers). AMS 14C dates were calibrated using Calib 6.01. (Stuiver and Reimer, 1993) and a standard reservoir age of 400 yr.

sec.title: Stable oxygen isotope measurements
sec.p: The stable isotope analyses on Neogloboquadrina pachyderma dextral coiling (N. pachyderma d.), Globigerina bulloides (G. bulloides) and Globorotalia inflata (G. inflata) were performed at the GMS laboratory of the Bjerknes Centre for Climate Research at University of Bergen on a Finnigan MAT 251 mass spectrometer equipped with an automatic ‘Kiel device’ preparation line. Foraminifera tests of grain size fraction > 150 µm (typically 6–10 specimens) were crushed and cleaned in an ultrasonic bath before being analysed. The reproducibility of oxygen isotope measurements is ±0.07‰ based on replicate measurements of carbonate standards. All results are reported δ18O in ‰ vs. PDB, using NBS 19 as the standard. The sampling interval of almost 1 cm for all three species N. pachyderma d., G.bulloides and G. inflata (at slightly lower resolution) provides a mean temporal resolution of about 30 years over the mid to late Holocene.

sec.title: Mg/Ca-derived SST reconstructions
sec.p: Approximately 50 tests of N. pachyderma d. were picked in the > 150 µm size fraction, weighed and crushed gently between glass slides to open chambers. The full trace metal method, including several rinses for clay removal, metal oxide reduction, and organic matter oxidation, was used (Boyle and Keigwin, 1985; Rosenthal et al., 1995). The samples were measured at WHOI using a Thermo-Finnigan Element 2 ICP-MS, and the methods of Rosenthal et al. (1999). Based on repeated measurements of three consistency standards with Mg/Ca ratios of 1.7, 3.3, and 5.0 mmol/mol. The long-term external precision at the time of the measurements was ~ 1.2%.

sec.title: Alkenone SSTs
sec.p: Alkenone measurements followed the procedure described in Moros et al. (2004) and Risebrobakken et al. (2010). We calculated the SST from Uk’37 according to Müller et al. (1998): Uk’37= 0.033T + 0.044. The analytical precision based on multiple extractions of sediment samples was better than 0.6°C for the Uk’ 37 index. The %C37:4 was calculated according to Bendle et al. (2005): %C37:4 = (C37:4/C37:2+C37:3+C37:4)*100. %C37:4 of mostly less than 4% and summer SSTs of > 8°C allow SST calculation using Uk’37:4 in the study area (Bendle and Rosell-Melé, 2004). Alkenones were analysed every 2–2.5 cm with a temporal resolution of about 60 to 70 years.

sec.title: Coccolith assemblage
sec.p: Coccolith analysis followed the procedure described in Giraudeau et al. (2010) and the composite DS97-2P and LO09-14 record discussed here is published in Solignac et al. (2009). The ‘NAD group’ discussed comprises of Gephyrocapsa muellerae, Syracosphaera spp., Calcidiscus leptoporus, Gephyrocapsa oceanic and represents the warm end-member of occolith assemblage.

sec.title: Ecology and water depth preferences of planktonic species N. pachyderma d., G. bulloides and G. inflata
sec.p: A number of papers have documented the ecology and water depth preferences of planktonic foraminifera in this region. Most recently, Chapman (2010) found N. pachyderma d., G. bulloides and G. inflata in great numbers during both the spring and summer seasons in sediment trap samples from the OMEX 2 site (49°N, 13°W).

G. bulloides is a near-surface (less than 60 m in the eastern North Atlantic) and late spring to summer species (Farmer et al., 2008; Schiebel et al., 1997), with the best relationship between Mg/Ca and temperature at 30 m water depth (Mekik et al., 2007). Studies report that δ18O G. bulloides-derived temperature estimates are generally 1–2°C colder than measured summer SSTs. This is consistent with the interpretation that G. bulloides largely reflects surface conditions during the late spring to early summer, although production may vary as a function of latitude (e.g. Chapman et al., 2000; Elderfield and Ganssen, 2000; Ganssen and Kroon, 2000). Chapman (2010) showed that G. bulloides can be strongly linked to spring bloom events.

North of Iceland N. pachyderma d. calcifies throughout the year at water depths between 30 and 40 m (Ostermann et al., 1998). However, in most regions, including the northeast Atlantic and Norwegian Sea, N. pachyderma d. favors warm, stratified surface waters (Sautter and Thunell, 1989) hence is a typical summer species (Berstad et al., 2003; Chapman, 2010; Fraile et al., 2009). In the northeast Atlantic, N. pachyderma d. appears to calcify at depths below 75 m (Ottens, 1992a), somewhat deeper than G. bulloides.

G. inflata is a deep-dwelling foraminifera and lives preferentially at the base of the seasonal thermocline (e.g. Ganssen and Kroon, 2000; Mortyn and Charles, 2003; discussion in Cléroux et al., 2007), where temperature is determined by the deep wintertime mixing. The calcification of this species during the warm season at mid-latitudes is confirmed by the plankton net study by Ottens (1992b) and OMEX2 study by Chapman (2010), and the physical characteristics of the ambient water during calcification are derived from the wintertime deep mixing.

The δ18O difference between G. bulloides and G. inflata (Δδ18O(G.bulloides-G.inflata)) is used as an estimate of water mass stratification (e.g. Hall et al., 2004). A study of surface sediments from the northeast Atlantic suggests Δδ18O(G.bulloides-G.inflata) values of around zero indicate cooler, well-mixed surface waters to the northwest of the Sub-Arctic Front, where deep wintertime mixing to at least 200 m depth extends into late spring/early summer (Ganssen and Kroon, 2000). In addition, Chapman (2010) observed close similarities in the flux patterns of the three species used here at OMEX2 site in the North Atlantic, suggesting that the taxon-specific δ18O measurements are more likely to reflect the record of surface stratification than differing seasonal production patterns.

Chapman (2010) analysed core top δ18O data and found that deep-dweller G. inflata typically has the most enriched δ18O values, indicative of colder temperatures. This is in accordance with our own core top data from a multicorer taken at Reykjanes Ridge in 2006 (Moros and Jansen, unpublished data, 2010). Our core topδ18O values are: 1.45‰ for G. bulloides, 1.47‰ for N. pachyderma d. and 2.06‰ for G. inflata. The difference in δ18O between G. bulloides and N. pachyderma d. in our core top sample from 58°N and 30°W is within the analytical uncertainty of the measurements.

sec.title: Results and interpretation
sec.p: δ18O G. bulloides (Figure 3a) values display a trend towards enriched δ18O values from c. 5 ka to the present (enrichment of about 0.3–0.4‰). Superimposed on this long-term trend are pronounced millennial-scale δ18O enrichments likely to reflect colder episodes centered at c. 5.6, 3.9, 2.7 and 1.3 ka. These δ18O enrichments display an amplitude of > 0.3‰. As is also the case for G. bulloides, the δ18O N. pachyderma d. record (Figure 3b) shows marked millennial-scale features. Enrichments are centered at 3.9 (1.7‰), 2.7 (1.8‰), and 1.3 ka (2.0‰). The amplitude of the warm/cold phases increases throughout the late Holocene with 0.2‰ at 3.9 ka, 0.35‰ at 2.7 ka to c. 0.5‰ at 1.3 ka. The δ18O values of thermocline species G. inflata (Figure 3c) display a long-term trend towards depleted δ18O values from 6 to c. 2 ka which reflects a clear warming. From 2 ka onward, a trend to enriched values is indicative of cooling in the thermocline. Phases of enriched δ18O values (cold intervals) are observed at c. 5.6, 3.9, 2.7 and after 1.5 ka. Most depleted values at c. 2 ka are parallel the strongest depletion in δ18O N. pachyderma d. This depletion seems to mark the warmest phase during the last 6 ka. However, the δ18O values of surface dweller N. pachyderma d. at 2.0 ka are just about 0.1‰ more depleted than those observed in the interval from 6 to 5 ka. The interpretation of our δ18O records, as predominantly reflecting temperature changes, is bolstered by the other proxy records obtained on DS97-02P (Figure 3d, f, g).

caption.p: DS97-02P proxy data versus age are shown. Five-point smoothed (thick curves) δ18O data of Neogloboquadrina pachyderma d. (a), Globigerina bulloides (b) and Globorotalia inflata (c); (d) Mg/Ca-derived temperatures from Neogloboquadrina pachyderma d., (e) alkenone % C37:4 calculated according to Bendle et al. (2005), (f) alkenone-derived SSTs, (g) % of coccolith North Atlantic drift species (from Solignac et al., 2009). Pronounced cold phases centred at 5.5, 3.8, 2.7 and 1.3 ka are marked with vertical grey bars.

sec.p: The five-point smoothed Mg/Ca-derived SSTs on N. pachyderma d., alkenone-derived SST and North Atlantic drift (NAD) coccolith data indicate a stepwise cooling trend for the late Holocene based on the amplitude of the cold millennial-scale events (Figure 3). The millennial-scale cold events identified in the oxygen isotope records are also evident in the other proxy records (note the lower resolution of those records). When considering alkenone SSTs and NAD coccolith maxima, a slight warming is observed at Reykjanes Ridge during the late Holocene (see also Balestra et al., 2010). This is also shown by δ18O G. inflata and δ18O N. pachyderma d. records. Most pronounced is a warm phase at 2.0 ka which is followed by a marked drop in alkenone SSTs (of 1.5°C, Figure 3f), Mg/Ca-derived temperatures (of 2.5°C, Figure 4d) and NAD coccolith data (Figure 4g), culminating in cold temperatures at 1.3 ka. The warm phase at 2.0 ka is associated with an increase in alkenone %C37:4 (Figure 4e) which suggests significant freshwater input (Bendle et al., 2005) likely via the EGC. This increased cold freshwater input may also explain the lack of warming in the spring-bloom δ18O G. bulloides record during that period (Figure 4b).

caption.p: Comparison of published δ18O records from South of Iceland. Alongside DS97-02P data, NEAP-4k (Hall et al., 2004) and RAPiD-12 (Thornalley et al., 2009) δ18O data of Globigerina bulloides (a), Globorotalia inflata (b) and the difference of δ18O of G. bulloides and G. inflata (d) are shown. δ18O record of Neogloboquadrina pachyderma d. is available for DS97-02P (c) only. Note, the increasing amplitude of δ18O maxima likely to reflect increasingly cold millennial-scale events in (c). Cold phases clearly seen in δ18O data centred at 5.6, 3.8, 2.7 and 1.3 ka are marked with grey bars in (a) and (c). A grey line (d) in the 0 values indicative of a well-mixed upper ocean surface layer (Hall et al., 2004).

sec.p: A high standard deviation of Mg/Ca on N. pachyderma d. measurements of replicates and the large amplitude of Mg/Ca-derived SST changes of successive samples (over 4°C) may be caused by intra-sample spread due to short-term frontal movements which may occur over shorter time spans than the time contained in each sample. These high-amplitude variations prevent us from calculating seawater salinity changes for the late-Holocene interval, and also make site-to-site comparisons of Mg/Ca records in the northern North Atlantic difficult. However, averaged Mg/Ca derived temperature changes on the order of 2.5°C for DS97-02P (Figure 4d) are also recorded for the late-Holocene interval by Thornalley et al. (2009; G. inflata), Farmer et al. (2008; G. bulloides), Richter et al. (2009; G. bulloides) and Came et al. (2007; N. pachyderma d.).

sec.title: Comparison of DS97-02P with other oxygen isotope data sets from south of Iceland
sec.p: We compare our DS97-02P oxygen isotope data with other δ18O records from south of Iceland, i.e. those from sites NEAP-4K (Hall et al., 2004) and RAPiD-12 (Thornalley et al., 2009). These three cores form a southwest to northeast transect, with DS97-02P site closest to the modern-day Sub-Arctic Front (Figure 1). Our new data set with c. 30 year temporal resolution has about twice the resolution as the published data from NEAP-4K and RAPiD-12 with c. 50 and > 60 years, respectively.

δ18O G. bulloides (Figure 4a). The NEAP-4K and our DS97-02P records agree well on longer-term timescales. Both records display a trend towards enriched δ18O values from c. 5 ka to the present, indicating a cooling trend in the surface waters. The trend is also evident in RAPiD-12 but there it starts later, at c. 4 ka and the change is not as pronounced as in the other cores. The RAPiD-12 δ18O G. bulloides values for the interval 5 to 6 ka are isotopically more enriched than those from the DS97-02P and NEAP-4K sites. The otherwise generally more isotopically enriched values in NEAP-4K and DS97-02P during the late Holocene indicate a stronger Sub-Arctic Front influence at these sites (as at present). Strongest Sub-Arctic Front influence (colder waters) at DS97-02P site is also indicated by (i) a higher amplitude of millennial-scale changes observed in DS97-02P than observed in the other cores and (ii) the DS97-02P record appears spikier, even though many peaks are resolved by several measurements and cannot be considered as outliers. There is not a good agreement between the three core records at millennial scales which is partly due to different sedimentation rates and record resolutions, but likely also due to age model uncertainties.

δ18O G. inflata (Figure 4b). The long-term trends in all three records agree well. A clear warming trend in the thermocline is observed from 6 to c. 2 ka. From 2 ka onward, a trend to enriched values is indicative of cooling in the thermocline. Not all phases of enriched δ18O values (cold intervals) in DS97-02P are clearly observed at the other sites, perhaps because of the lower resolution of the other records and the RAPiD-12 appears very spiky. Generally more enriched values in DS97-02P reflect maximum Sub-Arctic Front influence (colder waters) at this site.

δ18O N. pachyderma d. (Figure 4c). The δ18O N. pachyderma d. record of DS97-02P shows millennial-scale cold spells with a clearly increasing amplitude of the warm/cold phases throughout the late Holocene.

Δ18O(G.bulloides-G.inflata) (Figure 4d). Mainly driven by the δ18O G. inflata changes, the difference trends towards less negative from 6 ka in NEAP-04K and DS97-02P and reaches maximum values of around zero at c. 2 ka. This indicates a well-mixed surface water mass during the warm phase at 2 ka. The maximum values at 2 ka are also evident in RAPiD-12. Exceptionally enriched δ18O G. bulloides values in RAPiD-12 cause another maximum in the interval 6 to 5 ka, but is only evident in this core, which is the northernmost core of the three.

In summary, the longer-term features of δ18O records of the deep-dwelling thermocline recorder G. inflata at all three sites discussed compare well. However, there are marked differences in the long-term trends of the surface water recorders G. bulloides as well as millennial scales. Those can be best explained by the different site location with respect to the Sub-Arctic Front, hence by a different influence of cold EGC waters. In addition, a stronger Sub-Arctic Front influence compared with the northeastern sites causes a slightly colder thermocline at the Reykjanes Ridge.

At the Reykjanes Ridge site, located closest to the Sub-Arctic Front of the three sites we have compared, the δ18O records of the three planktonic species show characteristic features. Given the ecological and water mass preferences of the different species discussed above, it is likely that changes in the EGC strength (and frontal position) have strongest impact on the spring-bloom ocean surface records of G. bulloides. Hence, a stronger EGC influence during the late Holocene explains many of the features of the δ18O G. bulloides record: (i) the clear cooling trend, (ii) a generally more spiky record (because there is a variable influence of the front), (iii) the highest amplitude changes of most of the millennial cold spells and (iv) the lack of a warm phase at 2.0 ka which is clearly documented in the δ18O G. inflata and δ18O N. pachyderma d. records, and by other proxy records. By contrast, the δ18O N. pachyderma d. record appears smoother and lacks a clear cooling trend when looking at the warm intervals, which can be explained by its bias towards summer conditions (as discussed by e.g. Chapman, 2010). It is noteworthy, that despite the different amplitudes, the δ18O records of all taxa record the millennial-scale cold events, which are superimposed on the long-term near surface cooling trend (increasing EGC influence) in DS97-02P. An increasing influence of the EGC causing a closer position to and/or a more pronounced Sub-Arctic Front in the Reykjanes Ridge area during the late Holocene is also evidenced by high-resolution diatom data (Berner et al., 2008) which shows a strong increase in diatom flux from c. 4 ka in agreement with low-resolution DS97-02P diatom data published by Witak et al. (2005).

sec.title: Paleoclimatic implications
sec.p: All paleoclimate proxy records from Reykjanes Ridge site DS97-02P indicate that the amplitude of millennial-scale variability increased throughout the late Holocene. Ocean surface proxies point to increasingly colder millennial-scale cooling events which are likely linked to a stronger and fresher EGC as evidenced from a number of proxy records off West and East Greenland, and from North of Iceland. A stronger/fresher EGC caused a strengthening/shift of the Sub-Arctic Front towards the east over the Reykjanes Ridge during winter and spring. As mid-latitude storm tracks and the Sub-Arctic Front display a close association (Nakamura et al., 2004), an increase in meridional atmospheric circulation patterns may have also been favorable for accentuating differences in the water masses of the ocean Sub-Arctic Frontal zone. The thermocline temperatures based on deep-dwelling G. inflata, however, show a warming trend from 6 to 2 ka. When considering only the temperature during warm phases (between the cold spells) a slight warming trend of the warm phases during the late Holocene is observed and also indicated by a number of summer season related records at Reykjanes Ridge. In line with the observed warming at the thermocline, other foraminifer-based temperature records from the subpolar North Atlantic display a lack of significant warmth in the early and mid Holocene (Barker and Elderfield, 2002; Came et al., 2007; Farmer et al., 2008; Hald et al., 2007; Risebrobakken et al., 2003). The warming trend of warm intervals during the late Holocene is also seen in dinoflagellate data (Cortese et al., 2005). Several of the observed differences between different types of paleoclimate proxy records and their causes are discussed in detail in Andersson et al. (2009).

The prominent warm phase at 2.0 ka seems to be linked to the ‘Roman Warm Period’ and is a widely recorded feature in the northern North Atlantic region (Figure 5). The ‘Roman Warm Period’ seems to be much more pronounced than the ‘Medieval Climatic Anomaly’. Marine records from North of Iceland (Andrews and Giraudeau, 2003), Vøring Plateau (Risebrobakken et al., 2003), Barents Sea (Sarnthein et al., 2003), West Greenland (Moros et al., 2006b; Perner et al., 2011) and terrestrial wintertime precipitation records from maritime glaciers in northern Norway (Bakke et al., 2008) indicate a warm NAC and enhanced northwards moisture transport during the ‘Roman Warm Period’. A strong NAC with a well-mixed surface ocean layer at 2.0 ka is also indicated by the almost zero values of Δδ18O(G.bulloides-G.inflata) mainly driven by the warming at thermocline, and the maximum warmth documented by N. pachyderma d. at the Reykjanes Ridge. It remains to be seen if this warming is caused by a more sudden heat release after the pronounced 2.7 ka cooling event which was connected with a surface ocean cooling and perhaps a slowdown of the AMOC (Oppo et al., 2003). This mechanism is also proposed for rapid warmings after meltwater discharge events during the glacial. The sudden heat release and/or higher northward heat transport around 2.0 ka may have forced more melting, finally causing the even more pronounced cooling centered at 1.3 ka. The marked cooling trend from 2.0 to 1.3 ka is also seen in many marine records from the northern North Atlantic (e.g. Andrews and Giraudeau, 2003; Moros et al., 2004; Richter et al., 2009; Risebrobakken et al., 2003) and West Greenland (e.g. Moros et al., 2006b; Perner et al., 2011).

caption.p: Reykjanes Ridge oxygen isotope data (e) compared with marine and terrestrial data from a variety of sites in the North Atlantic region (site location see also Figure 1) showing the warm phase centred at 2.0 ka. Marine data: (b) foraminifer-based SST reconstruction from Barents Sea (Sarnthein et al., 2003), (c) δ18O Neogloboquadrina pachyderma d. from Vøring Plateau (Risebrobakken et al., 2003), (d) coccolith % of North Atlantic Drift species from north off Iceland (Andrews and Giraudeau, 2003), (f) cold water diatom % from West Greenland (Moros et al., 2006b). Terrestrial data: (a) winter precipitation at maritime glacier from northern Norway (Bakke et al., 2008) and (g) Greenland GISP2 mean-annual temperature (Alley et al., 1999). Note that the strong warm phase at 2.0 ka (grey area) is connected with a high winter precipitation at Lyngen in northern Norway.

sec.p: The increasing amplitude of the millennial-scale cold spells (at 5.6, 3.8, 2.7, 1.3 ka) of DS97-02P with the culmination in the ‘Little Ice Age’ at c. 0.3 ka (not recorded in DS97-02P because of loss of top sediment during coring, but recognized by e.g. Moros et al., 2004; Solignac et al., 2009; Feni Drift – Richter et al., 2009; West Greenland – Perner et al., 2011) is likely to have been caused by the late-Holocene trend towards a stronger and fresher EGC. This cooling and/or freshening of the EGC is likely to have increasingly impacted the SPG dynamics in the Labrador Sea and may have forced enhanced northward heat transport via the NAC due to a stronger influence of waters derived from the STG. In addition, biomarker IP25 (Belt et al., 2010) and dinocyst-based (Ledu et al., 2010) sea ice reconstructions also report cooler conditions and enhanced sea ice formation in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago (Baffin Bay) possibly linked to enhanced freshwater input to Baffin Current (BC) after 3 ka. The BC and the West Greenland Current merge to form the Labrador Current.

A stronger EGC influence on the central and western side of the North Atlantic during the late Holocene is also indicated when comparing the Reykjanes Ridge oxygen isotope data of N. pachyderma d. with those from a site located in the core of the NAC at the Vøring Plateau (Risebrobakken et al., 2003, Figure 6). Similar δ18O N. pachyderma d. values are observed during the mid-Holocene interval. However, a contrasting development is recognized for the late Holocene: colder temperatures due to stronger EGC influence at the Reykjanes Ridge and warmer conditions in the eastern Nordic Seas. Our data support the concept developed by Thornalley et al. (2009) over a longer-term timescale that the NAC flow is linked to the SPG dynamics. However, it remains unclear why the millennial-scale features, i.e. the cold events, occur simultaneously (within age model uncertainties) in the NAC core and in the Sub-Arctic Front area at the ocean surface and also in the thermocline. One possible explanation is a strong impact of external/solar forcing at millennial timescale (perhaps enhanced via sea-ice formation) as discussed by e.g. Renssen et al. (2006) and Plunkett and Swindles (2008) for the ‘2.7 ka cooling’ event. This is further supported by several dated mid- to late-Holocene cooling events recorded outside the Atlantic basin (e.g. Pérez-Cruz, 2006) that occurred at about the same time as the millennial-scale cold spells at the Reykjanes Ridge core.

caption.p: δ18O Neogloboquadrina pachyderma d. data sets of Sub-Arctic Front site DS97-02P and of MD99-2011 (Risebrobakken et al., 2003) a site located in the core of the North Atlantic Current (Figure 1) are compared. Please note the similar values in the mid-Holocene interval and the differing trends during the late Holocene. Despite the general different trends during the late Holocene there are synchronous millennial-scale events observed at both sites.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: Based on oxygen isotope data of three planktonic species (surface dweller G. bulloides and N. pachyderma d., and thermocline recorder G. inflata) from a site at Reykjanes Ridge recently located close to the Sub-Arctic Front, and in comparison with other proxy data from the same site, we suggest an increasing influence of colder East Greenland Current waters during the late Holocene. A stepwise long-term cooling trend is reflected by the increasing amplitude of millennial-scale cold spells centered at 5.5, 3.8, 2.8, 1.3 ka (and ‘Little Ice Age’ not covered here) clearly recorded in surface water proxies. The pronounced warm phase at 2.0 ka (‘Roman Warm Period’) recorded in almost all surface (except δ18O G. bulloides) and thermocline proxy data reflects the warmest period during the late Holocene in the northern North Atlantic region. It remains to be seen if this warm phase is caused by a NAC heat overshoot after the pronounced cooling seen at 2.7 ka in surface and thermocline data. A large drop in temperature of 2.5°C (Mg/Ca on N. pachyderma d.) and 1.5°C (alkenone SST), respectively, is observed from 2.0 to 1.3 ka and recognized in other areas. Our results support the concept developed by Thornalley et al. (2009) arguing for a strong influence of the SPG dynamics on the general northward heat transport (via increasing impacts from East Greenland Current dynamics) during the late Holocene. However, while this mechanism creates a means for changing the meridional heat transport in the ocean it cannot be the main driver of the synchronous (within age model uncertainties) millennial-scale events in the northern North Atlantic region.

ack.p: We thank the two referees for their very constructive reviews, and thanks to Kathryn Rose for technical assistance.
